awd_titl_txt: Real-Time Cosmology:  Using Extragalactic Proper Motions to Make Dynamical Cosmological Tests, to Measure Geometric Distances, and to Detect Primordial Gravitational Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this program is to use very small motions of distant galaxies and quasars to test cosmology, measure geometric distances, and detect gravitational waves. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, Dr. Darling will participate in Colorado's Fiske Planetarium live lecture series using the Science on a Sphere (SOS) exhibit that will enable communication of the broad ideas of cosmology, relativity, and other current research to the general public.

The proper motion measurements will be obtained from geodetic monitoring, the Gaia mission, and original observations at radio frequencies using Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI).  They can provide cosmological tests that are nearly model-independent. This work can measure or constrain: (1) The real-time growth and recession of structures, providing mass and distance measurements, (2) Extragalactic parallax for a statistical sample and individual galaxies, thus providing geometric distances, (3) The primordial stochastic long-period gravitational wave background and (4) Cosmic shear, rotation, bulk motion, and local voids that may manifest as an apparent acceleration attributed to dark energy.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to probe the dynamic universe in "real time" using the apparent motions of galaxies and quasars across the sky (proper motions).  Extragalactic proper motions can be apparent (caused by the observer's motion) or physical.  We used the Very Long Baseline Array, the Gaia mission, and their data archives to build galaxy and quasar proper motion catalogs that allowed us to probe our orbit around the center of the Galaxy, our motion compared to the rest frame of the universe, the gravity between galaxies and large structures of galaxies, the isotropy (uniformity) of the cosmological expansion, sound waves from the early universe, and primordial gravitational waves from the very early universe.  Several of these effects were detected and some were not.  We expect that most of these motions will be detected within the decade, and we provide forecasts for posterity.  We also developed the theoretical foundation needed for this and future work.

To convey these concepts, we created animated visualizations of the various proper motions expected over the whole sky and projected them onto a NOAA Science on a Sphere installation at the Fiske Planetarium at the University of Colorado, Boulder that can be shared with all of the installations worldwide.

This work formed part of two graduate PhD theses and supported several undergraduate researchers.  We also brought this science into the classroom, including courses focused on statistical analysis, scientific computing, and relativity and cosmology.
